Award.AwardTitle: FRG: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: DEFORMATION SPACES OF GEOMETRIC STRUCTURES
Award.AbstractNarration:
When can a global topology support a local structure modeled on a classical geometry? A "classical geometry" means the structure of a manifold invariant under a transitive action of a Lie group. For a fixed topology, the space of such structures is a natural object, with a rich geometry and symmetry of its own, associated with the topology and the homogeneous space. The study of deformation spaces of geometric structures was initiated by Charles Ehresmann in the 1930's. It unifies what have been disparate areas of research in the 19th century (crystallography, holomorphic differential equations and conformal mapping, development of projective geometry and non-Euclidean geometry). The subject became prominent through the influence of William Thurston in the 1970's. The prototype of this theory is the space of hyperbolic geometry structures on a closed surface, which by the classical uniformization theorem, identifies with the Teichmueller space of the surface. Our project explores three recent developments - geometric structures on 3-manifolds, higher Thurston-Teichmueller theory, and Anosov representations - where the rich structure of Teichmueller space generalizes to deformation spaces of more complicated geometries. The intimate relations of this subject with many other fields of mathematics underscores its central role in mathematics.

This project synthesizes disparate mathematical subjects: the topology of manifolds, various kinds of geometry, algebra and dynamics. The Moebius band is an example of a two-dimensional manifold with only one side. It describes, for example, the collection of all straight lines in the plane. The universe we live in is an example of a three-dimensional manifold. The position and velocity of a satellite or missile is described by a point in a six-dimensional manifold. Different kinds of geometries distinguish special properties of manifolds. The Moebius band is naturally described using the projective geometry inspired by the work of Renaissance painters. Cartographers used conformal geometry to produce more accurate maps of the world. Differential geometry enabled Einstein to develop his theory of gravitation. Chemists use the algebra of groups to classify crystals. The periodic table of chemical elements is intimately connected to the group of rotations of space. Much of this mathematical landscape remains unexplored. Using modern computers, students can contribute to this investigation. The exploration of explicit examples and their interactions provides problems for talented students, inviting them to the excitement of mathematical research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project concerns geometric structures on manifolds and the geometry, topology and dynamics on their moduli spaces.

Imagine a topology --- a collection of "points" loosely organized into a "space" which can be stretched, squeezed, but never broken or torn in a discontinuous fashion. For example, the sphere is a good topological model for our planet Earth --- like any mathematical idealization the earth is not exactly round, but up to continuous deformations it's round "to first approximation." It is not difficult to prove that one cannot find a metrically accurate world atlas --- that is, no collection of coordinate systems on the sphere will completely preserve the geometry as you go from one local coordinate system to an overlapping one.  In other words, as you proceed from one coordinate chart to a competing one, the natural (Euclidean) geometry must be distorted. In other words, the sphere admits no geometric structure modeled on ordinary Euclidean geometry.

On the other hand, the torus ---the topological surface of a doughnut, bagel, or an inner tube --- does admit a collection of Euclidean-geometry-compatible local coordinate systems. These geometric structures can easily be described mathematically as quotient spaces of the Euclidean plane by lattices, for example the set of pairs or (real) numbers modulo 1 --- that is, regard two numbers as equivalent to each other if they differ by an integer. In fact, the set of inequivalent Euclidean structures on the torus is an important space in many fields of mathematics, such as number theory, algebraic geometry, complex analysis and group theory.

The different ways of putting a geometry on a fixed topology can be organized into a "moduli space" --- the points of which describe the different geometric structures on the fixed topology. The research project has focused on the rich geometry that these moduli spaces inherit. In particular the various topological transformations of a surface (its mapping class group) will preserve much of the geometry of the moduli space. Thus a key point of our project has been to understand the rich geometry that our "space of geometries" itself enjoys.


Topology itself is a rich subject in low dimensions, and our project has concentrated in dimensions two and three. We restrict to manifolds, which are topological spaces where every point looks like it lives in neighborhood which is topologically Euclidean space. One important motivation is that these moduli spaces are spaces upon which the mapping class group acts, and provide an important tool for understanding the mapping class group and the rich topology enjoyed by surfaces.

Although these motivations seem theoretical, the origins and current applications will be very practical and related to scientific considerations. Much of the theory arose from efforts in the 19th century to understand crystals in terms of their symmetry groups (the theory of "crystallographic groups"). When the Euclidean geometry is replaced by Lorentzian geometry --- the geometry of Einstein's special relativity --- the resulting theory becomes much richer and intimately relates to hyperbolic non-Euclidean geometry, another mathematical theory born in the 19th century.  Lorentzian geometric structures have been a key focus of our research project.

Two- and three-dimensional manifolds have played an important role in modern physics deriving from quantum field theory. Algebraic properties  of curves on surfaces and the corresponding knots and links in three-space lead to a fascinating kind of "classical mechanics" on the moduli spaces.
